update.description:
Submeshes can be use as visuals and collisions using a new SDF tag:


```
#!xml

<geometry>
  <mesh>
    <uri>some_mesh_uri</uri>
    <submesh>
      <name>Name of the submesh</name>
      <center>true/false, where true = center vertices at 0,0,0</center>
    </submesh>
  </mesh>
</geometry>
```

This pull-request is an example: #!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/25/polaris-raise-steering-wheel-add-collision/diff

**Update:** Added tests.
update.title: Allow submeshes to be used as visuals and collisions

content.raw: `_meshName` refers to the name of the mesh in the MeshManager, and `meshName` is used to name that mesh uniquely for Ogre.
content.html: _meshName refers to the name of the mesh in the MeshManager, and meshName is used to name that mesh uniquely for Ogre.

content.raw: `geometry.sdf` has the description of what <center> does. The text in a pull-request is not documentation.
content.html: geometry.sdf has the description of what <center> does. The text in a pull-request is not documentation.

pull_request.title: Allow submeshes to be used as visuals and collisions

pullrequest.title: Allow submeshes to be used as visuals and collisions

content.raw:
``<center>true/false, where true = center vertices at 0,0,0</center>``

A more clear documentations is needed for this ... false leaves the mesh the way it is and true does what exactly? Centering all vertices at 0,0,0 would result in a dot. Or does ``<center>`` take in a new position for the center?



"This pull-request is an example: http://westernwheelersbicycleclub.memberlodge.com/sequoia"

wrong link? :)
content.html:
<center>true/false, where true = center vertices at 0,0,0</center>

A more clear documentations is needed for this ... false leaves the mesh the way it is and true does what exactly? Centering all vertices at 0,0,0 would result in a dot. Or does <center> take in a new position for the center?

"This pull-request is an example: http://westernwheelersbicycleclub.memberlodge.com/sequoia"

wrong link? :)
